what: Functions That Robert M Flight Finds Useful
title: Functions That Robert M Flight Finds Useful
text: flighttools personal package Robert M Flight, functions find needing regularly. Nothing meant required analysis, package doesn’t need installed something run. Instead, functions helpers, either providing interactive functionality, providing code can paste somewhere else something. like functions want use , go ahead install package. actually recommend fork package, look code borrow want make . Everything MIT licensed, go .

title: Functions That Robert M Flight Finds Useful
text: functions use probably notification functions. three, slightly different use cases, work roughly way: ft_beep_success_error: plays sound beepr code successful, different one error; ft_notify_success_error: creates visual notification using notify-send linux; ft_ntfy_success_error: sends network notification using ntfy package. typically use running long function, running targets pipelines. really nice, take whatever R code supply, evaluate , check code errored. didn’t error, just returns results. errored, tells , changing notification, returns results.

title: Functions That Robert M Flight Finds Useful
text: Many functions just spit code terminal copy document code file. example, title block use regularly. ’s enough template, like use consistent one. way, can package installed, hard dependency, just copy output project Rmd qmd file.
code: library(flighttools) ft_title_block() title: "A Good Title" author: "Robert M Flight" date: last-modified date-format: YYYY-MM-DD HH:mm format:    docx:     keep-md: true   html:     toc: true     embed-resources: true bibliography: bibliography_file.json

title: Functions That Robert M Flight Finds Useful
text: ’m using targets, also like able rename file outputs current date, can keep track versions, well zip Word figure directory share others.

title: Functions That Robert M Flight Finds Useful
text: work academic environment, lot data analysis collaborators. really want provide information roughly much time spend various tasks working , don’t want manually track . Therefore, built set relatively simple time tracking functions package. way works, set file timekeeping recorded via start stop statements. file path defined environment variable. set top level .Renviron. See ft_setup_timekeeping(). also set categories tasks allowed record another environment variable, restrict categories recording, personally, ’ll keep changing . Actual timekeeping log entries comma separated, don’t use comma’s comments, anything else. functions : ft_setup_timekeeping(): run give code setting things ; ft_tk_logtask(): log starting stopping tasks; ft_tk_removelast(): remove last entry case messed ; ft_tk_summarize_time(): summarize many days ’ve worked particular projects; ft_tk_parselog(): parse display log file.

title: create limma code — ft_limma_code
text: helper provides template limma code programmatically set differences one wants extract.

title: create limma code — ft_limma_code
code: ft_limma_code() #> #' run limma #> #' #> #' Run limma code between two levels or factors. #> #' #> #' @param data_in a matrix of values, columns are samples #> #' @param data_info data.frame of attributes #> #' @param contrast the attribute, and factors #> #' #> #' @examples #> #' data_in = matrix(rnorm(200), nrow = 10, ncol = 20) #> #' rownames(data_in) = paste0("f", seq(1, 10)) #> #' colnames(data_in) = paste0("s", seq(1, 20)) #> #' data_in[, 1:10] = data_in[, 1:10] + 2 #> #' #> #' data_info = data.frame(sample_id = paste0("s", seq(1, 20)), group = rep(c("g1", "g2"), each = 10)) #> #' # g2 is the reference #> #' # LFC should all be positive #> #' contrast = c("group", "g2", "g1") #> #' #> #' run_limma(data_in, data_info, contrast) #> #' # g1 is the reference #> #' # LFC should all be negative #> #' contrast = c("group", "g1", "g2")   #> #' run_limma(data_in, data_info, contrast) #> run_limma = function(data_in, data_info, contrast) { #>   data_info[[contrast[1]]] = factor( #>     data_info[[contrast[1]]], #>     levels = contrast[c(2, 3)] #>   ) #>  #>   design_matrix = model.matrix( #>     as.formula(paste("~", contrast[1], sep = " ")), #>     data = data_info #>   ) #>   ncol_design = ncol(design_matrix) #>   colnames(design_matrix)[ncol_design] = contrast[1] #>  #>   out_contrast = paste0(contrast[3], " / ", contrast[2]) #>  #>   data_in = data_in[, data_info$sample_id] #>  #>   # depending on your data type, you may need to add an extractor, #>   # log-transformation, imputation, or combinations of them prior #>   # to running the actual limma calculations below #>  #>   lm_fit = limma::lmFit(data_in, design_matrix) #>   e_fit = limma::eBayes(lm_fit) #>  #>   results = limma::topTable( #>     e_fit, #>     coef = contrast[1], #>     number = Inf, #>     p.value = 1 #>   ) #>   results$feature_id = rownames(results) #>   results$contrast = out_contrast #>   return(results) #> }

title: save plot to temp — ft_plot_temp_file
text: in_plot plot save filename file save . Default underscore make easily findable width width saved plot height height saved plot units units use res resolution ... parameters ragg::agg_png()

title: setup timekeeping — ft_setup_timekeeping
code: ft_setup_timekeeping() #> Copy and modify these lines to a commonly used .Renviron file: #>  #>   R_FT_TK_LOGFILE=/path/to/timekeeping_dir/.timekeeping/.timekeeping.csv #>   R_FT_TK_CATEGORIES=qcqa,analysis,packagedev,cleaning,reporting,writing,anythingelse #>    #>   Run this in an R session: #>      #>   fs::dir_create('/path/to/timekeeping_dir', recurse = TRUE) #>   fs::file_create('/path/to/timekeeping_dir/.timekeeping.csv'
